reviewText: Belle Starr (1848-89) was the first of the female outlaws, and even to this date, more than a century and a half later, she heads up a very short list. Other female "outlaws" include Ma Barker and Bonnie Parker.FWIW - I don't include such notable western gals as "Big Nose Kate", "Calamity Jane", "Etta Place" and "Cattle Kate" as these women were not really outlaws.The film is not exactly up to historic standards, though it is true that Starr was from Missouri, was an expert sharp shooter, and eventually married Sam Starr (her second marriage, having already become an outlaw when married to her first husband). Her story was popularized in dime novels beginning in 1889 and in films beginning in 1928. She was played by Jane Russell in "Montana Belle" (1952), Elizabeth Montgomery in "Belle Starr" (1980), and Pamela Reed in "The Long Riders" (1980).Beautiful Gene Tierney (1920-91) was nominated for an Oscar for "Leave Her to Heaven" (1944) and appeared in more than 40 films, the most notable of which were "Tobacco Road" (1941), "Laura" (1944), "Razor's Edge" (1946), and "The Left Hand of God" (1955). She was known for her escapades with famous personalities like Tyrone Power, Ally Kahn, and JFK.Handsome Randolph Scott (1898-1987) plays Sam Starr. Scott started in silent films and made a name for himself in the 40s playing a variety of characters in a variety of films - "My Favorite Wife" (1940), "To the Shores of Tripoli" (1941), "Captain Kidd" (1945), "Home Sweet Homicide" (1946) - but by the 50s he was appearing exclusively in B westerns . He amassed a fortune from California real estate investments, and retired from film making because he considered his performance in "Ride the High Country" (1962) to be a good note to go out on.Handsome Dana Andrews (1909-92) plays the Yankee Major who burns Belle's mansion and imprisons her brother. Andrews appeared in over 100 films, including memorable roles in "The Westerner" (1941), "Ox Bow Incident" (1943), "Laura" (1944), "A Walk in the Sun" (1945), and "The Best Years of Our Lives" (1946).Chill Wills (1902-78) plays a member of the gang. He appeared in over 100 films, usually as the grizzled sidekick and occasional comic foil. He's best remember for his Oscar nominated role as Beekeeper in "The Alamo" (1960), but he also put in memorable performances as Uncle Bawley in "Giant" (1956) and the storekeeper in "Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid" (1973).Shepperd Strudwick (aka John Shepherd) plays Belle's brother. He made dozens of films in the 30s and 40s and then transitioned to TV where he was nominated for 2 daytime Emmys for "Love of Life" (1951) and "One Life to Live" (1968).Louise Beavers (1902-62) plays Belle's servant. She appeared in more than 100 films from 1923 to 1960 and is probably best known for her role in "Imitation of Life" (1934) and for her TV show "Beulah" (1950-3).Irving Cummings (1988-1959) directs. He was a popular actor in the silent era and also worked as a director, making westerns and light hearted comedies. He was nominated for an Oscar for "In Old Arizona" (1928).The NY Times called it "a stange melange of Technicolored fuss-and-feathers" and "a pompously operatic fiction," although they did note that "Here and there the film comes to life."Popular westerns of the 1940s often focused on the gunfighter or the outlaw - "The Return of Frank James" (1940), Gary Cooper's "The Westerner" (1940), John Wayne's "3 Godfathers" (1948), "Dark Command" (1940) with John Wayne and Roy Rogers, "Duel in the Sun" (1946) with Gregory Peck, John Ford's "Ox Bow Incident" (1943), and Howard Hughes' "The Outlaw" (1943). Though there were exceptions -  Fritz Lang's "Western Union" (1941) with Randolph Scott, John Ford's  "My Darling Clementine"  (1946), "Fort Apache" (1948), and "She Wore a Yellow Ribbon" (1949), and John Wayne's "Red River" (1948) - the focus on the outlaw in Westerns mirrored the focus on the gangster in crime dramas.1941 was a terrific year for films - "Citizen Kane", "The Maltese Falcon", Sergeant York", "How Green Was My Valley", Meet John Doe", "Buck Privates", "They Died with Their Boots On", "The Sea Wolf" "High Sierra", "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde", and "A Yank in the RAF". The big Oscar winner was "How Green Was My Valley" (Director, Picture, Supporting Actor)This is a pretty ordinary film, but the ending is particularly good albeit sentimental.
summary: "She's what the white folks calls a legend"
Title: Belle Starr [Region 2]

reviewText: Now, I am a big fan of Randolph Scott and Gene Tierney. They both tried but were lost with the script. Scott just is not much of a bad guy or in this case a man without conviction that could be construed as of two minds. Too much subtle messaging. Gene is never allowed to cast off her dress. She acts as Scarlett in the 'fiddle-dee' manner then goes vengeful; followed by a fit of conscience.To see her with those beautiful eyes staring to imply hate or love is way over done. The studio could have ruined the career of both Tierney and Scott with this presentation. The Director is amatuerish at best with this film.
Title: Belle Starr [Region 2]

reviewText: Typically listed as a western, in large part for star Randolph Scott, this is one of those westerns-in-name-only; it's really a post-Civil War "Gone With the Wind" knockoff about feisty Confederate sympathizing beauty Belle Shirley (Gene Tierney), and the two men who vie for her affections, Union officer Thomas Crail (Dana Andrews) and and rebel Sam Starr (Scott). Guess which one she marries? Belle tries to keep her estate in Missouri going after the war, and when that fails, turns to raiding with the charismatic guerilla fighter Starr, hiding out in the hills as the reward on them keeps going up.Like GWTW this is one of those southern-sympathizing films in which the slaves are happy and the masters kind (if patronizing), and the Confederate sympathizers noble and courageous while the Union men are - well, actually the Union men aren't so bad here; the real problems arise when Sam Starr recruits some no-accounts from Texas who are more interested in raping and pillaging than the Lost Cause.  Clint Eastwood'sThe Outlaw Josey Walesexplored that area of the Civil War era much better, and it's not the only film that did so.  But it's clear that "Belle Starr" wants us to see the former slaveholders as noble and just, and that their ex-property regard them so, and that things would have been much better if not for those nasty Yankees, especially the evil unscrupulous raiders who profited after the war.  Anybody who has problems with the attitudes in the  much more famous Civil War picture of two years earlier, will almost certainly have the same issues with this one.And "Belle Starr" doesn't offer the same film-making compensations that GWTW did. The story is laughable and not particularly well put together by director Irving Cummings and his crew, and the trio at the center of the story all contribute some of their less-distinguished performances. It's not so much that they're bored or boring, but that they all seem very one-note - "hey Randolph, just be excited in this scene", that sort of thing. Even the color isn't all that terrific though it's certainly serviceable enough. What it adds up to for me is a film that is definitely one of the weakest of the 60+ with Randolph Scott that I've seen, and probably the worst film of 1941 I've seen; for completists only.
summary: Attractive cast doesn't quite compensate for dull script, action in would-be Civil War epic
Title: Belle Starr [Region 2]

reviewText: Okay, so it's not exactly a subtle attempt at cloning "Gone With The Wind" - it's all too transparent at times. Yes, it's dated, from a liberated perspective,(but remember the era that it's set in, as well as the time in which it was produced)with some excruciating dialogue. But it has its redeeming virtues, entertainment value and deserving of a DVD release after years of obscurity on channels that us civilians can't afford to add to basic peasant vision.A dramatized, sanitized account of the most notorious female outlaw, who rode alongside such notables as Jesse James, it boasts gorgeous cinematography in Techincolor, a good musical score, and wonderful costumes. Whenever Randolph Scott is associated with a project, you know it will be a decent western.However, the best relationship in the film is the one that exists between Belle Starr and Major Thomas Grail, the Yankee commander and childhood chum who must bring her to justice in spite of his deep love for her. It is the sparks between the beautiful Gene Tierney and the handsome Dana Andrews that really makes this movie, preceding the film noir classic "Laura" and two later collaborations.The gorgeous, fiery Belle Shirley (Gene Tierney) sympathizes with the Southern rebels, so much so that she even helps Captain Sam Starr (Randolph Scott) hide from the Yankee forces in Missouri by letting him stay in her home after he is wounded.When the Yankees discover this, they set her house aflame and burn it to the ground. Defying them, she joins Starr and his followers at their secret hide-out and begins assisting them in robberies and raids, chasing Carpetbaggers and running afoul of the Yankees. The bandit queen and her outlaw lover marry and continue with their Confederate cause. But only when things get far too dangerous does Belle realize that death may be too high of a price to pay for what she so immensely believes in. Sam Starr insists that there be one more dangerous escapade, after agreeing to give up his personal vendetta. This leads to tragic consequences when Belle unwittingly puts herself in the line of fire, placing her own life in jeopardy.The low-life drunkard, Jasper Tench, who expects the much emphasized reward money for killing Belle Starr only gets disdain and hatred from the townsfolk having deprived them of their heroine, and Starr turns himself in, and both he and his enemy, Grail, grieve over the woman they both loved.I found the age difference between Scott and Tierney distracting (going by what I remember, as I haven't seen the film in years), and also obvious is the battle that Tierney has with the accent that she assumes throughout the film. I know people having been complaining about the racist elements throughout the movie (as with GWTW),but I like to think of it as a lesson on how things have changed. Chill Wills is in fine form as one of the rebels, Shepperd Strudwick (billed as John Shepperd)is quite good as Belle's rather ill-fated brother Ed, while Louise Beavers (best remembered from her role in John Stahl's 1934 version of "Imitation Of Life")does a good turn as Mammy Lou, although her performance doesn't hold a candle to Hattie McDaniel's portrayal in GWTW.It's a good movie, and it's nice to watch and a good substitution if you're not in the mood to indulge in a three-and-a-half hour epic.Note to FOX: as you are releasing many of your older films on DVD, do likewise with "Belle Starr". Don't leave this and many other gems to rot away in the studio vault!
summary: An Interesting Epic Worthy Of A Region 1 DVD Release
Title: Belle Starr [Region 2]

reviewText: I suspect this film is not in wide release for it's neutral to south-leaning on the civil war mostly.  There is also some racist dialogue common to some films of the times.  Most available prints I've seen have been fairly dark and it is good to verify quality on any purchase.  The story while mostly fiction is still a pretty interesting tale pulled from actual people and events.  Tierney's fairly weak early acting debut is saved by the performance of Scott and Andrews mainly and the usual added flair of Chill Wills.  The score and directing is pretty weak, but it is worth seeing if you can get a good print.
summary: Worth seeing, if you can find a good print
Title: Belle Starr [Region 2]
